title: Cloudflare Workers Tutorial for Beginners: Build Your First API in 10 Minutes
subtitle: A practical, step-by-step guide to building and deploying your first serverless API
description: Learn Cloudflare Workers step-by-step. Build and deploy your first serverless API in 10 minutes with code examples. Perfect for developers coming from Node.js, Express, or AWS Lambda.
author: tamyla

faq.question: What is Cloudflare Workers?
faq.answer: Cloudflare Workers is a serverless platform that runs JavaScript code at the edgeâ€”in 330+ data centers worldwide. Unlike AWS Lambda which runs in specific regions, Workers run close to your users everywhere, resulting in sub-50ms response times globally. Workers use V8 isolates (the same engine that powers Chrome) and start in under 5ms with no cold starts.

faq.question: Is Cloudflare Workers free?
faq.answer: Yes! Cloudflare Workers has a generous free tier: 100,000 requests per day, 10ms CPU time per request, and access to Workers KV (key-value storage). This is enough for most personal projects, MVPs, and small production apps. The paid plan ($5/month) includes 10 million requests and more CPU time.

faq.question: How do I get started with Cloudflare Workers?
faq.answer: Getting started is simple: 1) Install Wrangler CLI with 'npm install -g wrangler', 2) Authenticate with 'wrangler login', 3) Create a project with 'npm create cloudflare@latest', 4) Write your Worker code in src/index.js, 5) Deploy with 'wrangler deploy'. Your API will be live on a *.workers.dev URL in seconds.

faq.question: What can I build with Cloudflare Workers?
faq.answer: Cloudflare Workers can handle: REST APIs, authentication/authorization, image optimization, A/B testing, redirects/rewrites, caching logic, webhooks, scheduled tasks (cron), WebSocket servers (with Durable Objects), AI inference (with Workers AI), and full-stack apps with database (D1) and storage (R2).

faq.question: What is the difference between Cloudflare Workers and AWS Lambda?
faq.answer: Key differences: 1) Cold starts: Workers start in <5ms vs Lambda's 500ms-10s, 2) Location: Workers run in 330+ cities vs Lambda's ~30 regions, 3) Billing: Workers charge CPU time only vs Lambda's wall-clock time, 4) Pricing: Workers free tier is 100K req/day vs Lambda's 1M req/month, 5) Runtime: Workers use V8 isolates vs Lambda's containers.

faq.question: Can I use npm packages with Cloudflare Workers?
faq.answer: Yes, but with caveats. Workers support npm packages that don't rely on Node.js-specific APIs (like fs, net, child_process). Most utility libraries (lodash, date-fns, zod) work perfectly. For Node.js APIs, Cloudflare provides compatibility flags and polyfills. Check the Cloudflare docs for the Node.js compatibility matrix.

howToSteps.name: Install Wrangler CLI
howToSteps.text: Open your terminal and run: npm install -g wrangler. This installs Cloudflare's command-line tool for Workers development.

howToSteps.name: Authenticate with Cloudflare
howToSteps.text: Run: wrangler login. This opens your browser to authenticate with your Cloudflare account.

howToSteps.name: Create a new Worker project
howToSteps.text: Run: npm create cloudflare@latest my-first-worker. Select 'Hello World' template and TypeScript when prompted.

howToSteps.name: Write your Worker code
howToSteps.text: Open src/index.ts and modify the fetch handler to return JSON responses, handle routes, and process request data.

howToSteps.name: Test locally
howToSteps.text: Run: wrangler dev. Your Worker runs locally at localhost:8787. Make changes and see instant updates.

howToSteps.name: Deploy to production
howToSteps.text: Run: wrangler deploy. Your Worker is now live at https://my-first-worker.<your-subdomain>.workers.dev
